glosses: To twist something, to hold something from both ends and turn it in opposite directions; to wring, to pirl, to screw.
To give the mouth an acrid or bitter taste, or a puckering or drying sensation, such as after eating an unripe persimmon or a quince.
(of stomach, of bowels) To hurt, to twinge, to gripe.

etymology: Inherited from Ottoman Turkish بورمق (burmaḳ, “to twist or screw, to wring, to strangle, to castrate, for the bowels to gripe”), from Proto-Turkic *bür- or *bur- (“to twist, to wring”). Possibly evolved from the form Proto-Turkic *bügür-, which was derived from Proto-Turkic *bük- (“intransitive; to be squeezed, to be strangled”).
